segments.en: Numbered Discourses 9
1. Awakening
6. Association

segments.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi … pe … āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:
segments.en: There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:
“Reverends, you should distinguish two kinds of people:
those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.
You should distinguish two kinds of robes:
those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.
You should distinguish two kinds of almsfood:
that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.
You should distinguish two kinds of lodging:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
You should distinguish two kinds of market town:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
You should distinguish two kinds of country:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
You should distinguish two kinds of people:
those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.’

segments.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
Take a person of whom you know this:

segments.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
segments.en: ‘When I associate with this person, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.

segments.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca kasirena samudāgacchanti;
segments.en: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

segments.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho na bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo rattibhāgaṃ vā divasabhāgaṃ vā saṅkhāpi anāpucchā pakkamitabbaṃ nānubandhitabbo.
segments.en: And the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is not being fully developed.’ In this case you should leave that person at that very time of the day or night, without asking. You shouldn’t follow them.
Take a person of whom you know this:

segments.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
segments.en: ‘When I associate with this person, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.

segments.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca appakasirena samudāgacchanti;
segments.en: But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.

segments.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho na bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo saṅkhāpi anāpucchā pakkamitabbaṃ nānubandhitabbo.
segments.en: However, the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is not being fully developed.’ In this case you should leave that person after reflecting, without asking. You shouldn’t follow them.
Take a person of whom you know this:

segments.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti;
segments.en: ‘When I associate with this person, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.

segments.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca kasirena samudāgacchanti;
segments.en: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

segments.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo saṅkhāpi anubandhitabbo na pakkamitabbaṃ.
segments.en: But the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is being fully developed.’ In this case you should follow that person after reflection. You shouldn’t leave them.
Take a person of whom you know this:

segments.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti;
segments.en: ‘When I associate with this person, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.

segments.en: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.

segments.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo yāvajīvaṃ anubandhitabbo na pakkamitabbaṃ api panujjamānena.
segments.en: And the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is being fully developed.’ In this case you should follow that person. You shouldn’t leave them, even if they send you away.
‘You should distinguish two kinds of people:
those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.’

suttaplex.blurb: Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.
